<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR5860</span> - Health education theory and practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR5860">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Suzanne Willey">Ms Suzanne Willey</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Suzanne Willey">Ms Suzanne Willey</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5860&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR5860">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in M6006 and M6031</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will equip nurses and midwives with the knowledge and skill to apply health education theory to all areas of practice regardless of setting or context.</p>
<p>The aim of this unit is to research and apply health education theories to improve the health and wellbeing of individuals and communities.</p>
<p>The content is delivered in three modules. The first module examines traditional models and behavioural approaches to health education. The second module explores contemporary theories and considers their relevance to health education. The third module applies contemporary health education theory into clinical practice.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse traditional models and behavioural change approaches to health education;</li>
<li>Analyse behavioural change theory from the perspective of long term change and complex psycho-social situations;</li>
<li>Evaluate contemporary health education theory in changing health behaviours;</li>
<li>Examine the social context of where individual and communities live and how this relates to promoting health and health education;</li>
<li>Construct and critique health education strategies to include consideration for varying levels of health literacy;</li>
<li>Design a health education plan with a focus on long term change in a complex environment.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written assessment (1,500 - 2,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Critical analysis (1,500 - 2,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Health education plan (2,500 words) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Flexible: 12 hours per week comprising guided readings, online activities; workshops and /or tutorials, including self-directed learning.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Nursing &amp; Midwifery</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">CIV3284</span> - Design of concrete and masonry structures<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CIV3284">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-civil-engineering.html">Department of Civil Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeff Walker">Professor Jeff Walker</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ye Lu">Dr Ye Lu</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Daniel Kong">Dr Daniel Kong</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CIV3284&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CIV3284">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CIV2206.html">CIV2206</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>CIV2226</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces students to concrete technology, reinforced concrete and masonry design. Three major topics areas are basic concrete materials technology, reinforced concrete analysis and design, and masonry basics and design. The unit provides a balanced coverage of the practical construction aspects, analytical methods and design aspects.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify types of cements, aggregates, and admixtures in concrete.</li>
<li>Describe the properties of fresh and hardened concrete.</li>
<li>Describe and decide concrete specifications.</li>
<li>Design concrete mix and assess concrete mix proportions for various applications.</li>
<li>Analyse loads and their representation on structures.</li>
<li>Design reinforced concrete and masonry structures using relevant Australian Standards.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 50%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a Pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours lectures, 2 hours practice classes and 7 hours of private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/civil-engineering">Civil Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS1317</span> - Renaissance worlds: Conflict, art, invention<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS1317">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-history.html">History</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Carolyn James">Associate Professor Carolyn James</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Carolyn James">Associate Professor Carolyn James</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS1317&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS1317">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit examines European society from the fourteenth to the seventeenth century. It analyses the cultural, religious, intellectual and political developments that characterised Europe in this period, such as self-conscious efforts to revive the Classical past, artistic and political patronage, gendered social expectations, debates about religious and scientific truths, and early European encounters with the 'New World'. The unit also considers the history and significance of the concept of the 'Renaissance', and its impact on understandings of both modernity and the pre-modern past.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will have developed competencies in:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understanding major themes of Renaissance European history;</li>
<li>Interpreting and discussing critically documents and artefacts from the Renaissance period;</li>
<li>Evaluating the arguments of historians about Renaissance society;</li>
<li>Recognising and discussing critically the stereotypes conjured up by the term 'renaissance';</li>
<li>Identifying and evaluating resources relevant to a historical question;</li>
<li>Planning and constructing clear written arguments;</li>
<li>Delivering oral presentations.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/history">History</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE4011</span> - Earth science research project B<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE4011">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate, Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Alexander Cruden">Professor Alexander Cruden</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Alexander Cruden">Professor Alexander Cruden</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=EAE4011&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE4011">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in the Master of Science</p>
<p>Satisfactory completion of <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE4010.html">EAE4010</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students undertake a project, involving original research in one of the School's research themes, which encompass a diverse range of modern Earth Science topics, including: geochemistry, geochronology, geophysics, remote sensing, Geographic Information Systems, spatial data science, soil science, petrology, palaeontology, geodynamics, structural geology, tectonics, biogeography, physical geography, climate science, paleoclimate, hydrogeology, hydrology, ore deposits geology.  A full list of projects will be made available to students prior to commencing their MSc program.</p>
<p>The research project may be experimental, computational, theoretical or field based in nature, or it may involve a combination of these research paradigms. Each student will be assigned an academic supervisor (or supervisors), who will oversee the research project and provide mentoring. Students will be required to undertake a comprehensive literature review and report their preliminary results via a seminar. The major outcomes of the project will be communicated in the form of a thesis. Students will also be required to defend their research outcomes via an oral examination.  For most students their project will be continued into the second year of the MSc program; hence <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE4000.html">EAE4000</a></span> will lay the foundations for a substantial ongoing research project in the second year of the degree.</p>
<p>As part of their research training, students will be affiliated with one of the School's research groups (aligned with their research project) and will be required to attend weekly group meetings, seminars and colloquia. Opportunities will also be provided to students to receive training in specialist areas associated with their research project, e.g., analytical methods, technical computing, visualisation of data, specific experimental techniques, field techniques, etc.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand, use and explain the basic concepts and principles of the research literature which underpin the chosen area of research in Earth Science.</li>
<li>Synthesise and interpret the knowledge gained in the study of the underpinning research literature. This leads to the ability to identify a niche topic or topics within this existing body of literature, which represents a gap in current knowledge. This problem should be suitable for original research.</li>
<li>Advance our understanding of an existing problem or problems in the chosen area for original research.</li>
<li>Present the results of the original research in written form as a thesis, and also present key thesis results in oral form as a preliminary seminar.</li>
<li>Defend the results of the original research in an oral exam.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is the second half of a two-semester research project.</p>
<p>Literature review: 20%</p>
<p>Oral presentation: 10%</p>
<p>Thesis: 70%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours per week</p>
<ul>
<li>Attendance at weekly group meetings (half hour per week)</li>
<li>Attendance at seminars and colloquia (half hour per week)</li>
<li>At least half hour per week of consultation with the supervisor</li>
<li>Specialist training (approximately half hour per week)</li>
<li>Preparation of literature review (approximately 1 hour per week averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>Preparation for the seminar (approximately half hour per week averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>Preparation of Progress report (approximately 1.5 hours per week averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>19 hours of independent research per week</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Master of Science in Earth Science</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BEX3725</span> - Engaging with international business - Europe<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BEX3725">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mark Crosby">Professor Mark Crosby</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3725&amp;tpCode=T1-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 1</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3725&amp;tpCode=TRI-B-29&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester B</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3725&amp;tpCode=TRI-C-29&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester C</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BEX3725">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-city-melbourne.html">City (Melbourne)</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester B 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Trimester C 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-prato.html">Prato</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 1 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Students must have completed at least 72 Monash credit points of study prior to enrolling in this unit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit requires students to examine a broad range of social, cultural, legal and political issues that can impact on the strategy and operations of businesses operating in a global business environment. Through the use of readings, case studies, and an analysis of current events students are confronted with some specific challenges of doing business in a global context. This unit focuses on developing skills, addressing various global issues and how they affect business, as well as aspects of global citizenship, cultural sensitivity and effective teamwork.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>recognise issues affecting businesses operating in a global context</li>
<li>develop and present strategic responses to specific issues affecting businesses operating in a global context with due consideration to sustainable, responsible and ethical business practices</li>
<li>acquire team skills including team leadership, collaboration, problem-solving, decision-making, communication and presentation skills</li>
<li>develop reflective practice skills in relation to individual learning.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUT5002</span> - Practice and research in public health nutrition<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUT5002">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-nutrition-dietetics-and-food.html">Department of Nutrition, Dietetics and Food</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Evelyn Volders">Evelyn Volders</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Suzanne Kleve">Dr Suzanne Kleve</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUT5002&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUT5002">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT3002.html">NUT3002</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT3082.html">NUT3082</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT4001.html">NUT4001</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT5001.html">NUT5001</a></span> and must be enrolled in Master of Dietetics.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Please note: The teaching dates for this unit vary from the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">standard teaching dates</a><span class="hbk-print-url">standard teaching dates (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span> for this teaching period.</p>
<p>Unit discontinuation and penalty dates for these units are different to other units taught in the same teaching period.</p>
<p>Please refer to the information available on the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">Faculty non standard teaching dates page</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Faculty non standard teaching dates page (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates</a>)</span> to avoid <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">academic and financial penalties</a><span class="hbk-print-url">academic and financial penalties (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is predominantly a fieldwork experience that will challenge students to integrate their academic training and to synthesise knowledge into a practical public health nutrition project based in the community setting. The unit requires students to manage a project that addresses a public health nutrition issue. Students will participate in program planning within a work environment and provide tangible benefit to their participating organisation. Students will be responsible for designing a project, collection and analysis of data and synthesis of findings into a report.  Principles of information evaluation, workload management, communication, teamwork and responsibility for project management will also be developed.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Apply the social, environmental, economic and political determinants of nutrition status to a priority public health nutrition area.</li>
<li>Plan, implement and evaluate systems based, population health approaches and solutions to priority nutrition issues.</li>
<li>Apply the research process using appropriate methods of collection and analysis for both qualitative and quantitative data.</li>
<li>Contribute to an evidence-based, population approach to improve population nutrition health in a community setting.</li>
<li>Advocate for policy change to benefit health and nutrition outcomes for populations.</li>
<li>Employ critical and scientific writing and communication skills to document and report findings of project in professional and scientific fora.</li>
<li>Practice professional leadership to promote the role of nutrition.</li>
<li>Establish effective working partnerships, networks, collaborations with a range of team members and stakeholders.</li>
<li>Adopt a questioning and critical approach in all aspects of practice and evaluate practice on an on-going basis.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>30-38 hours per week for 7 weeks plus an additional 2 days site/project orientation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Project proposal (2,000 words) (20%) Group</li>
<li>Placement deliverables (4,000 words) (30%) Group</li>
<li>Scientific Abstract (250 words) (10%)</li>
<li>Oral poster presentation (10%) Group</li>
<li>Standardised oral interview (20%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Competency Reflection (500 words) (10%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Evidence of Competence (ungraded Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>30-38 hours per week for 7 weeks plus an additional 3 days project orientation and in</p>
<p>semester sessions.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/dietetics">Dietetics</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5553</span> - Field studies in sustainable development<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5553">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-politics-and-international-relations.html">Politics and International Relations</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Eleanor Gordon">Dr Eleanor Gordon</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->tba
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5553">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>APG4553</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>This unit is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">international study program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">international study program (<a href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad</a>)</span> that requires an application to be enrolled and may incur additional cost.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">Summer Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Summer Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This field studies unit explores the concept of sustainable development in Asia and  draws attention to the practical constraints and issues associated with translating the Sustainable Development Goals into regional policy and practice. Working across multiple development sectors and with a range of local partners, the unit provides students with the opportunity to apply inter-disciplinary and cross-cultural problem solving skills outside the classroom, while contributing to a local organisation, as detailed in point 3 below.</p>
<p>The unit is divided into four phases. Students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Attend pre-departure preparatory workshops in Melbourne. Topics covered include understanding the Sustainable Development Goals and their implementation, an overview of sustainable development issues in the host country, and an overview of cross-cultural norms, safety and logistical information.</li>
<li>Participate in a week long journey across a specific region/area  in the host country where students will meet with a variety of groups to discuss sustainable development challenges. Themes include:  post-conflict transitions, livelihood development, sustainable resource management, gender empowerment, disaster management, migration; climate change, ecotourism; urbanisation, disabilities, and sustainability education.</li>
<li>In the host-country, work  in a small team to provide a service to a partner organisation addressing a specific organizational need over a two-week period. Examples of a service includes conducting a needs assessment, designing and writing monitoring and evaluation reports, event coordination, stakeholder research, conducting a gender analysis, designing training programs, writing project and grant proposals, or developing a communication and media strategy.</li>
<li>Attend a briefing workshop prior to leaving the country to share and reflect on their work.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students are expected to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify, describe, and interpret the concept of sustainable development in the context of development practice;</li>
<li>demonstrate advanced understanding of the complex constraints, issues and opportunities associated with translating the Sustainable Development Goals into practice;</li>
<li>critique and integrate theoretical knowledge and frameworks acquired through their studies to practical situations;</li>
<li>apply practical skills including working in interdisciplinary teams and cross-cultural skills;</li>
<li>reflect upon skills required to work in the area of sustainable development and identify skills they wish to develop further and;</li>
<li>effectively present complex ideas about sustainable development practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Fieldwork in an overseas country </p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/environment-and-governance">Environment and governance</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-development-practice">International development practice</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">BIO1062</span> - Biology 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BIO1062">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biological-sciences.html">School of Biological Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Richard Reina">Associate Professor Richard Reina</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Song Keang Peng">Associate Professor Song Keang Peng</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BIO1062&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BIO1062">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1011.html">BIO1011</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>BIO1711, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS1021.html">BMS1021</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1022.html">BIO1022</a></span></p>
<p>Students in S2007 Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Biomedical Science are prohibited from enrolling in this unit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>A study of the biology of whole organisms, organ systems and cells, including molecular genetics, and the effect of environmental parameters on biological functions. The biology of microbes and animals is emphasised. Ecological factors that are biologically important at the level of integrated whole organisms and at the cellular, subcellular, and biochemical levels are considered for each organism under study. As for <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1011.html">BIO1011</a></span>, the unit is structured to encourage self-paced learning with considerable feedback on individual performance.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate a coherent understanding of biology by articulating the methods of biology and explaining why current biological knowledge is both contestable and testable through further inquiry;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an understanding of concepts and processes related to
molecular genetics, genetic engineering, and the physiology of organ systems, including homeostasis, nervous and muscular-skeletal systems, animal reproduction and development and nutrition;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an understanding of microbial diversity, in particular how it relates to human health and disease;</li>
<li>Gather, synthesise and critically evaluate information relevant to biology by applying practical techniques (including Gram staining, gel electrophoresis, and spectrophotometry) and tools to conduct an investigation within the laboratory;</li>
<li>Demonstrate competency in designing experiments, gathering data and analysing and presenting summative data in meaningful and accurate ways;</li>
<li>Communicate scientific principles and information underlying biology-related topics in written or oral formats and using appropriate conventions for scientific attribution;</li>
<li>Work and learn independently and collaboratively while exercising personal, professional and social responsibility that recognises the importance of practising science sustainably, ethically and safely.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Practical's, online activities, and assessments: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Two 1-hour lectures, one hour of set reading and quizzes, and one 3-hour practical or equivalent online activities</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKC3110</span> - Market analysis and strategy development<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKC3110">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pingping Qiu">Dr Pingping Qiu</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pingping Qiu">Dr Pingping Qiu</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKC3110&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKC3110">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKC1200.html">MKC1200</a></span> or equivalent and two units (12 points) from the Department of Marketing.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF3121.html">MKF3121</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKW3121.html">MKW3121</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKC3130.html">MKC3130</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF3131.html">MKF3131</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKC3140.html">MKC3140</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF3151.html">MKF3151</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKS3440.html">MKS3440</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKW3440.html">MKW3440</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKW3610.html">MKW3610</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKB3804.html">MKB3804</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit applies a market focus to the process of analysis and strategy development. Using marketing planning as a framework, the contribution of marketing strategies to the attainment of firm goals is explored.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>distinguish the nature of marketing decisions that a firm makes according to the hierarchy of strategy</li>
<li>explain the contribution that marketing makes to the value of the firm</li>
<li>conduct analysis of the internal and external environments of an organisation that informs marketing strategy development</li>
<li>formulate and recommend marketing strategies that add measurable value to the organisation</li>
<li>develop the written and oral communication skills required to justify a strategic recommendation.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MED5102</span> - Contemporary developments in clinical practice: Patient safety<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MED5102">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Barton">Associate Professor Peter Barton</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Parasakthi Navaratnam">Professor Parasakthi Navaratnam</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julia Harrison">Dr Julia Harrison</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Stuart Marshall">Dr Stuart Marshall</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Rafidah Atan">Associate Professor Rafidah Atan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MED5102&amp;tpCode=FY-32&amp;tpYear=2019">Full year (extended)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MED5102">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year (extended) 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year (extended) 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>2012 pre-reqs: MED4071, MED4082 and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED4000.html">MED4000</a></span></p>
<p>2014 pre-reqs: MED4171, MED4182, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED4200.html">MED4200</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED4000.html">MED4000</a></span> or GMC4151, GMC4162, GMC4200 and GMC4000.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED5091.html">MED5091</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED5092.html">MED5092</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED5100.html">MED5100</a></span>. Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 4531, 4532, 4533, M6011, M6018, M6019.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Medical practitioners are frequently required to respond to emerging and consolidating innovations and policies related to clinical practice. MED5102 further develops the concept of 'readiness to practice' and focuses upon the development of students' understanding of the principles of Patient Safety and the related clinical competencies. The unit will provide students with an understanding of the role of research in Patient Safety and the application of these principles and practices in diverse contexts. The unit will have the capacity to respond to other issues/innovations/policy changes as they arise in medical practice.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify and describe the principles of Patient Safety;</li>
<li>Recognise individual practitioner, patient and institutional methods and strategies used to ensure Patient Safety principles are upheld;</li>
<li>Demonstrate competence in Patient Safety practices in simulated settings;</li>
<li>Contribute actively to the development and implementation of Patient Safety practices; and</li>
<li>Critique and apply current scientific and medical research related to Patient Safety.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit requires students to undertake off-campus clinical placements. In the clinical setting students will have an opportunity to apply theory to practice under supervision. Attendance is mandatory for the clinical component of each unit.Students must be aware of the faculty's Clinical Placement Guidelines.Students will not be permitted to attend any clinical placements unless they have current valid Working with Children and Police checks, and have a satisfactory immunisation status, all of which must be submitted to Faculty. </p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will not be individually graded, but all assessments will be a hurdle requirement. Each assessment item will need to be successfully completed to pass this unit.</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Observed Patient Safety Skills Assessment</li>
<li>Online assessment tasks

<p>Hurdle requirement: Students must attend a minimum of 80% tutorials and clinical placements to pass this unit.</p>
<p>If you are unable to attend a session, you may be eligible for In Semester Special</p></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/medicine-and-surgery">Medicine and surgery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">BIO3021</span> - Marine biology<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BIO3021">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biological-sciences.html">School of Biological Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Dustin Marshall">Professor Dustin Marshall</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Dustin Marshall">Professor Dustin Marshall</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BIO3021&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BIO3021">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>12 points from level two BIO units including <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO2181.html">BIO2181</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO2231.html">BIO2231</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit investigates the organisms and the processes that drive marine ecosystems. We deal with the trophic structure of marine ecosystems, including primary and secondary production, microbial loops, food webs and their importance for marine fisheries. The implications of the characteristic life cycles of marine organisms to their geographical distribution are also considered. These topics are placed in the context of specific marine ecosystems including coastal habitats, coral reefs, open oceans, the deep sea and polar ecosystems. The practical component comprises a field trip (fee payable) either to Heron Island in December or the Queenscliff Marine Station in February where students work in small groups on specific aspects of marine biology.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the diversity and ecological importance of marine life;</li>
<li>Explain the fundamental physiochemical and physiological processes underlying the productivity of marine environments;</li>
<li>Explain the ecological dynamics of marine ecosystems;</li>
<li>Discuss the impact of human activity on the sustainability of marine ecosystems;</li>
<li>Demonstrate advanced scientific skills in project design, data collection, analysis and writing.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Practical work/field work/project work: 40%</p>
<p>Mini quizzes: 10%</p>
<p>Attendance at one of the two field trips offered for this unit is a mandatory hurdle for this unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Two 1-hour lectures, equivalent of 3 hours laboratory/field work per week</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/developmental-biology">Developmental biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/ecology-and-conservation-biology">Ecology and conservation biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/plant-sciences">Plant sciences</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/zoology">Zoology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BFM5973</span> - International finance<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BFM5973">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-banking-and-finance.html">Department of Banking and Finance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mohammed Shaiban">Dr Mohammed Shaiban</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mohammed Shaiban">Dr Mohammed Shaiban</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BFM5973">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in course B6007</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Topics include working capital management, capital budgeting and funding decisions (capital structure and cost of capital) incorporating the identification of foreign exchange risks and their management as well as their financial reporting implications.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify motives and evaluate strategies for foreign direct investment</li>
<li>understand the impact of and strategies to manage risks associated with international business</li>
<li>acquire a sound knowledge of issues surrounding the financing of international business</li>
<li>develop oral presentation skills in communicating complexities surrounding international business</li>
<li>develop an ability to work independently, lead and participate in teams from diverse cultural and social backgrounds by producing a presentation relating to an international business issue</li>
<li>demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by BFM5973.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<li class="breadcrumbs__item breadcrumbs__current"><a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units">Units</a></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT9135</span> - Data communications<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT9135">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Guido Tack">Dr Guido Tack</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT9135&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT9135&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT9135">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>FIT9020, FIT5135</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit will introduce students to fundamentals of data and computer communications methods and techniques. It covers: ISO and TCP/IP layered protocols; physical layer concepts: data transmission methods, signal encoding and digital data communication techniques; data link control protocol, multiplexing methods; WAN and LAN networking fundamentals; internetworking and transport protocols; and basic concepts of network security.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>describe the underlying fundamental theories and models of transmitting data across a communication channel;</li>
<li>identify and describe the concepts and theories of standard network protocols;</li>
<li>describe the functions and architectures of local area networks, wide area networks and the Internet;</li>
<li>identify and describe fundamental concepts of network security including common threats and countermeasures;</li>
<li>evaluate several different design options and formulate a simple network design.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%; In-semester assessment: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:

<ul>
<li>Two hours of lectures</li>
<li>One 2-hour laboratory</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):

<ul>
<li>A minimum of 8 hours independent study per week for completing lab and project work, private study and revision.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGF5928</span> - Strategic leadership<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGF5928">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jess Co">Dr Jess Co</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jess Co">Dr Jess Co</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGF5928&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGF5928&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGF5928">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will critically evaluate the dynamic nature of strategy making and strategic leadership. Students will become familiar with key strategic concepts and frameworks to analyse organisational strategy, and understand the importance of strategic thinking in leadership development. Students will learn the principles of analysing industry dynamics and strategic responses to competitive challenges in order to improve organisational performance. Using the understanding of strategy and leadership principles students will learn to develop strategic leader competence while assessing the impact of culture and gender on leadership style and advancement. Students will also appreciate that strategy making and organisational leadership are not top down processes, they are both top down and bottom up.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>critically analyse the strategic nature of organisational leadership</li>
<li>develop an understanding of strategy and leadership as dynamic processes</li>
<li>analyse the role of strategic decisions in a range of contexts and understand approaches to addressing strategic decision-making challenges</li>
<li>develop creative solutions to challenges associated with industry dynamics when responding to competitive challenges, and improving organisational performance.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">MDC5210</span> - Interaction design studio 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MDC5210">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=In Dae Hwang">Dr In Dae Hwang</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=In Dae Hwang">Dr In Dae Hwang</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5210&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5210&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MDC5210">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4110.html">MDC4110</a></span> or by permission</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4201.html">MDC4201</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4202.html">MDC4202</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4215.html">MDC4215</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4216.html">MDC4216</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC5201.html">MDC5201</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC5215.html">MDC5215</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit advances knowledge, methods and principles in interaction design and focuses on furthering the practical and conceptual skills developed in preceding units. In the studio students will be exposed to a broad range of interactive system design methods from holistic thinking and operational thinking to self-organization, and will explore the significance and complexity of contextualization required in systemic approaches in the design process. A major design project encourages students to develop research skills and experience in applying methods and principles of system design to solve complex interaction design issues.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Research and integrate advanced interactive system design concepts, approaches, theories and principles to their own design practice;</li>
<li>Utilise contextual diagrams and interfaces as core components in a design outcome with consideration for the basic needs of target users;</li>
<li>Apply research, problem-solving methodologies and advanced technical skills to plan and manage complex interaction design solutions from initial concept to final resolution;</li>
<li>Communicate ideas and concepts to critically reflect and justify own design through a process of observation, analysis, selection, interpretation and expression;</li>
<li>Critically analyse and evaluate the rationale for integrating interactive technologies in a design solution;</li>
<li>Observe and employ occupational health and safety appropriate to studio practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours per week including 8 contact hours plus 16 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MCE5205</span> - Research in ART (designing and applying)<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MCE5205">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-obstetrics-and-gynaecology.html">Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Temple-Smith">Associate Professor Peter Temple-Smith</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mulyoto Pangestu">Dr Mulyoto Pangestu</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MCE5205&amp;tpCode=S2-32&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester (extended)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MCE5205">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-monash-medical-centre.html">Monash Medical Centre</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester (extended) 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester (extended) 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in course code M6010</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit allows students to apply the practical skills and knowledge they have acquired in Semester 1 to design and execute a research project. Collaborating with others, students will follow the standardised methods of scientific enquiry to look for gaps in our current understanding of a subject area, propose appropriate experimental design, develop experimental methods to test their hypotheses, statistically analyse their findings and report these findings in a globally accepted format that could be considered for publication.</p>
<p>Students will develop their presentation skills (both oral and written), and their ability to work as part of a productive team to complete both practical and theoretical tasks.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate research laboratory practices in reproductive biology</li>
<li>Use appropriate statistical tools to analyse data in reproductive sciences</li>
<li>Present research findings through both oral and written communication</li>
<li>Create effective written communications to express ideas within the standardised scientific format.</li>
<li>Work effectively as a scientific team to solve a problem</li>
<li>Reflect on the experimental process and on group participation and learning</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written research report (3500 words) (60%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Oral poster presentation (30%)</li>
<li>Research plan (10%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>This is a self-directed practical based unit, with a high number of contact hours for hands-on research experience.</p>
<p>For on-campus students, this unit is conducted over ten weeks in Semester 2. It is expected that students plan, implement and present the findings of their research project under the guidance of their research supervisor.</p>
<p>For off-campus students working in an ART unit, an in-clinic research project will be conducted within this timeframe. For students employed by clinics unable to offer a research project, a simulated online project will be provided.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>Research project can be conducted at their place of relevant employment (no requirement for face-to-face attendance). Alternatively, a simulated online project can be offered with timelines for completion similar to on campus students.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/clinical-embryology">Clinical embryology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
